com.ibm.jikes.skij.util
Class Invoke

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.jikes.skij.util.Invoke
public class Invoke
extends Object

The Invoke class implements a high-level interface to Java reflection. Using Invoke, you can dynamically create objects of arbitrary classes, send methods to them, examine and change their fields.

In versions of Java prior to Java 2, only public classes and members can be accessed reflectively. In Java 2, nonpublic classes and members can be accessed if the security manager allows it. Invoke will try the appropriate method in either case.

Primitive values may be required by some methods or constructors, may be returned as values by some methods, and may be used as the value for some fields. In such cases, the methods of Invoke accept or return the wrapped form (i.e., a java.lang.Integer object will be used for values of type int).

See Also:
ExtendableClassLoader, Method, Constructor, Field

public static final boolean java11

public static final boolean java2
True if we are running in Java 2 or above. If this is true, then non-public classes and members can be accessed.

Method Detail

invoke

public static Object invoke(Object obj,                            String methodName,                            Object[] args)                     throws NoSuchMethodException,                            Throwable
Invoke a method on an object, given the object, a method name, and an array of arguments. The appropriate method is found as defined in the Java Language Specification, section 15.11, using the dynamic types of the arguments as substitutes for the static type information used in normal method invocation. If an appropriate method is found, it is invoked on the object and arguments using standard reflection.
Parameters:
obj - the target object.
methodName - the name of the method to invoke.
args - the arguments to the method, in the form of an array.
Returns:
the result of the method invocation (possibly null).
Throws:
NoSuchMethodException - if no suitable method can be found.
Throwable - the method might throw an arbitrary exception.

invoke

public static Object invoke(Class myClass,                            Object obj,                            String methodName,                            Object[] args)                     throws NoSuchMethodException,                            Throwable
Invoke a method on an object or class, given the class, object, a method name, and an array of arguments. This form of invoke is useful for invoking static methods.
Parameters:
myClass - the target class.
obj - the target object (ignored and can be null for static methods).
methodName - the name of the method to invoke.
args - the arguments to the method, in the form of an array.
Returns:
the result of the method invocation (possibly null).
Throws:
NoSuchMethodException - if no suitable method can be found.
Throwable - the method might throw an arbitrary exception.

getMethod

public static Object getMethod(Object obj,                               String methodName,                               Object[] args)                        throws NoSuchMethodException
Return a method object, given a target object, method name, and arguments. This is analogous to invoke, but returns the appropriate method object rather than actually performing the invocation.
Parameters:
obj - the target object (ignored and can be null for static methods).
methodName - the name of the method to invoke.
args - the arguments to the method, in the form of an array.
Returns:
a method object.
Throws:
NoSuchMethodException - if no suitable method can be found.

Set the value of a field.
Parameters:
object - the target object.
fieldName - the name of the field as a string.
value - the new value for the field.
Throws:
NoSuchFieldException - if the field can't be found
IllegalAccessException - if the field can't be accessed.
IllegalArgumentException - if the new value is not suitable for the field.

poke

public static void poke(Class myClass,                        Object object,                        String fieldName,                        Object value)                 throws IllegalAccessException,                        NoSuchFieldException
Set the value of a field. This form is useful for static fields, in which case object is ignored and may be null.
Parameters:
myClass - the target class
object - the target object (ignored and may be null for static fields).
fieldName - the name of the field as a string.
Throws:

IllegalArgumentException - if the new value is not suitable for the field.
